title: Western Carolina's Newsome leads strong ground game
text:
Western Carolina's Newsome leads strong ground game Keith Jarrett , kjarrett@citizen-times.com 4:24 p.m. EDT October 6, 2015 Tailback Detrez Newsome is the catalyst for Western Carolina's strong ground game. Newsome leads the Southern Conference in rushing (119 yards per game) and all purpose yards (195 ypg). WCU tailback Detrez Newsome (21) is averaging 8.1 yards per carry, best in the Southern Conference. (Photo: Mark Haskett) Detrez Newsome keys WCU ground game Leads SoCon in rushing (119 yards per game) 2 CONNECT 5 TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
ASHEVILLE â€” In senior Troy Mitchell, Western Carolina has one of the most dynamic quarterbacks in the Southern Conference, a run/pass playmaker who is the school's all-time leader in total offense (7,499) and ranks eighth in the history of the league in that category. 
But in order to make the offense better, coach Mark Speir's plan is to perhaps take the ball out of Mitchell's hands more often. 
It sounds weird, but it makes sense. 
In the Catamounts' 33-21 win over Presbyterian last week, tailback Detrez Newsome rushed 25 times for 189 yards, both career highs, highlighted by a 72-yard touchdown sprint on an up-the-middle running play. 
It was the third straight 100-yard rushing game for the 5-10, 205-pound sophomore from Raeford and the second straight contest in which he broke a long scoring run - against Tennessee it was a 64-yard sprint. 
And it happened in part because Speir decided after a 55-10 loss in Knoxville that a strong running game would bring out the best in his quarterback. 
"Troy's strong suit is not to sit back and throw from the pocket," Speir said. "He's at his best when he is in the flow of the offense, running out on the edge and throwing on the move. 
"And when we get our running game going and Troy can do play action, we're at our best." 
Newsome leads the Southern Conference in rushing with 479 yards despite averaging less than 15 carries per game. His workload increased against Presbyterian because senior Darius Ramsey was out with a concussion, but Speir suggested Newsome's productivity demands that he get more carries. 
"If Darius is healthy, we're going to use all three backs (including freshman Corey Holloway, with 145 rushing yards in three games), but Detrez is just running the ball extremely well," Speir said. 
"He's a powerful runner, and he has shown some excellent speed with those long runs the last two games." 
Newsome is all for more carries and more emphasis on the ground game. 
"When coach said we were going to run the ball more, I was all for that," he said with a laugh. 
A talented kick returner (285 yards, 21.9 yards per return), Newsome leads the SoCon in all-purpose yardage (195 per game) and teams with Mitchell (fifth in the league in total offense at 232 yards per game) to provide a solid 1-2 punch for the WCU offense. 
"Troy had his best game against Presbyterian (14-of-24 passing, 226 yards and 75 yards rushing, including a game-clinching 36-yard scoring run in the fourth quarter), and I think it was because it was our best running game (316 yards rushing)," said Speir. 
"Troy was at ease and in the flow of the game, and that's when we can utilize him the best." 
"Using the run to set up the pass really worked (vs. Presbyterian)," said Newsome, who rushed for 488 yards and nine touchdowns last season as a freshman. 
"Troy really played well and looked comfortable running that type of offense." 
The Cats (2-2, 0-1) on Saturday begin a stretch of five straight SoCon games that will define their season, a 3:30 p.m. home game vs. Mercer (2-2, 0-1). 
Despite giving up 391 yards on the ground last week vs. Wofford in a 34-33 overtime loss, the Bears rank first in the SoCon in rushing defense, allowing an average of just 136 yards per game.
